awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Translation Potential of a Wearable, Brain-computer Interface System for In-home Stroke Rehabilitation
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this I-Corps project is the development of a novel stroke rehabilitation system, achieved through the introduction of a wearable electrode system designed for in-home use. Stroke, a leading cause of disability, places substantial economic burdens on individuals and healthcare systems. The project's innovative approach could empower stroke survivors to engage in rehabilitation within the comfort of their homes.  This technology could not only enhance patient outcomes but also help address the economic challenges associated with stroke disabilities. This project could also signify a critical advancement at the intersection of technology and healthcare, with the potential to improve the landscape of stroke rehabilitation by making it more inclusive, convenient, and economically viable for a broader segment of the population.

This I-Corps project utilizes experiential learning coupled with a first-hand investigation of the industry ecosystem to assess the translation potential of the technology. The solution is based on the development of a wearable system designed for in-home stroke rehabilitation, integrating an electrode system embedded with an electroencephalography (EEG)-based brain-computer interfaces (BCI). The components include a stretchable mesh headset featuring durable electrodes, a wireless system resilient to interference, and intelligent machine learning algorithms facilitating unsupervised brain-computer interface operation. By addressing the challenges associated with conventional gel-based electrodes and the necessity for expert supervision, this technology represents a novel advancement in neural recording capabilities. The fusion of brain-computer interface technology, wireless communication, and machine learning algorithms could not only make stroke rehabilitation more accessible, convenient, and technologically advanced but also holds promise for diagnosing and treating a variety of neurological disorders.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
This I-Corps project aimed to assess the commercial potential of a wearable, EEG-based brain-computer interface (BCI) system for home-based stroke rehabilitation. The envisioned system integrates EEG-driven functional electrical stimulation (FES) to enable stroke survivors to engage in motor recovery exercises independently at home, improving access to neurorehabilitation while reducing costs and logistical burdens associated with clinic-based care.

 

During the 7-week program, the Neurawear team conducted 102 customer discovery interviews across key stakeholder groups, including stroke survivors, caregivers, neuro-rehabilitation clinicians, hospital administrators, insurance providers, and rehabilitation technology distributors. These interviews revealed a strong, validated need for an affordable, easy-to-use, clinically effective solution for at-home stroke rehabilitation. A rental pricing model of $200–$250/month was consistently preferred and deemed feasible by both end-users and providers.

 

The team also identified regulatory and reimbursement considerations critical to market adoption. Insights from insurers and regulatory advisors confirmed that a pathway to FDA 510(k) clearance is viable and that the system could potentially be covered under an emerging reimbursement code (E-code) similar to one already in development for comparable neuro-rehabilitation devices.

 

Beyond stroke rehabilitation, the project has broader implications for the fields of wearable neurotechnology, digital health, and assistive medical devices. The team’s findings help advance understanding of how to bring novel BCI technologies into the home setting, laying the groundwork for future applications in Parkinson’s disease, epilepsy, and other neurological disorders.

 

Importantly, this program supported the professional development of the entrepreneurial and technical leads, who gained critical experience in market research, regulatory strategy, and commercialization planning. The results also informed the formal incorporation of Neurawear Inc. as a Delaware C-Corp to carry the technology forward through clinical validation, FDA submission, and market launch.

 

This project represents an important step toward democratizing access to effective neuro-rehabilitation, especially for underserved populations. The Neurawear team is now well-positioned to develop and deliver a transformative at-home therapy platform that meets the needs of stroke survivors, clinicians, and healthcare systems alike.

 


Last Modified: 03/27/2025
Modified by: Huiliang Wang
